metadata.title: Rheological and micro-structural characterization of bitumen modified with carbon nanomaterials

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Rheological and micro-structural characterization of bitumen modified with carbon nanomaterials
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2018.12.173 0950-0618/ 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors at: School of Transportation Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, PR China (D. Wang).
E-mail addresses: zhongjing.hit@gmail.com (J. Zhong), dawei.wang@hit.edu.cn (D. Wang).
Qilin Yang a, Quan Liu b, Jing Zhong a,⇑, Bin Hong a, Dawei Wang a,b,⇑, Markus Oeser b a School of Transportation Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, PR China b Institute of Highway Engineering, RWTH Aachen University, Mies-van-der-Rohe-Street 1, 52074 Aachen, Germany
h i g h l i g h t s
CNTs and Gr enhance the stiffness, rutting resistance and high temperature performance of bitumen. CNTs and Gr remarkably changed the glass transition temperature and increase low-temperature property of bitumen. The optimal CNTs and Gr content of bitumen are 1.5% and 1% by mass of bitumen, respectively. Gr exhibits a better modification enhancement and compatibility with bitumen than CNTs.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 26 August 2018 Received in revised form 21 December 2018 Accepted 24 December 2018
Keywords: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) Graphene (Gr) Rheological properties Micro-structural Modification mechanism
a b s t r a c t
To investigate the rheological and micro-structural properties of bitumen modified with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (Gr), bitumen samples with different contents of CNTs and Gr were manufactured and characterized from both rheological and micro-structural perspective. A frequency sweep and multi stress creep recovery (MSCR) were conducted by dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) to investigate the rheological properties of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) tests were applied to survey the glass transition temperature. The homogeneity of the dispersion and the interaction between bitumen and nanomaterials were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The results indicated that the incorporation of CNTs and Gr enhance the stiffness, rutting resistance, elastic recovery performance, pavement service life and high temperature performance of bitumen. The performance improvements were attributed to an increase in the crosslinking degree of the binders induced by the carbon nanomaterials. Bitumen binders modified with 1.5% CNTs and 1% Gr are found to be the optimal mixtures. Compared to CNTs, Gr is more compatible with neat bitumen and the effect of Gr modification is observed to exceed that of CNTs at the same content. This may be due to the sheet-like surface morphology and larger specific surface area of Gr.
2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, increased traffic-induced loading and climate change have resulted in complex conditions which toughened the requirements for the performance of highway pavement materials [1,2]. Conventional pavement materials are not expected to meet the practical demands for present and future highway pavement construction. Therefore, pavement materials, which provide a higher quality, increased safety, a higher reliability and environmental sustainability must be developed.
Modified bitumen is increasingly used in high-grade highways; thus the development of new bitumen modifiers has attracted great attention [3–5]. Traditional modifiers, for example fibers, crumb rubber and ceramic can improve the performance of bitumen, such as rutting resistance, cracking resistance, fatigue resistance, adhesive bonding and anti-aging, etc [6–9]. However, research increasingly concentrating on the introduction of nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene (Gr), nanofibers, nanoceramics and nano-clays to modify bitumen due to their high temperature sensitivity, high ductility, large surface area, high strain resistance, and low electrical resistivity [10–13].
The nanomaterials are believed to meet the specific requirements for the development of highway pavement materials. Therefore, the nanomaterials are introduced into the pavement engineering field, by using them to modify bitumen. In the last
decade, various kinds of nano-particles have been used to improve the properties of asphalt materials. It has been proved that the addition of nanoparticles can prolong the fatigue life and decrease the permanent deformation of asphalt materials. This may be ascribed to their surface effects, small size effects and quantum size effects [14,15]. Moreover, nanoparticles can enhance the complex shear modules, reduce the phase angle and improve the rheological performance of basic bitumen, which is attributed to their high specific surface area and small size [16–18]. In addition, the incorporation of the nano-clays, nano carbon fiber or nanoceramic and spherical particles (nano-ZnO, nano-SiO2, nano-TiO2, and nano-CaCO3) can also significantly improves the lowtemperature cracking resistance as well as the high-temperature performance. These performance improvements were attributed to an increase in the crosslinking within the binder induced by the nanoparticles [19–22]. It is evident that, nanomaterials are playing an increasingly important role in the process of bitumen modification.
CNTs and Gr are two typical Nano-materials sourced from graphite. Both CNTs and Gr consist of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms and are intrinsically compatible with bitumen. CNTs exhibit a cylindrical nanostructure that is shaped like a tube of carbon atoms while the carbon atoms in Gr are covalently bonded in a twodimensional (2D) honeycomb lattice [20,23]. CNTs and Gr offer a combination of highly favorable thermal, mechanical and electrical properties all of which are potentially beneficial for the performance of bitumen [18,24,25]. With respect to bituminous pavements, numerous researchers have stated and validated that bitumen modified with carbon nanomaterials exhibits good thermal oxidation properties, improved aging resistance as well as higher elasticity and viscoelasticity in comparison with the base bitumen [24,26].
Many studies regarding bitumenmodification with CNTs and Gr have been reported and comprehensive investigations regarding rheological properties, fatigue behavior and durability were discussed [18,23–27]. However, these studies discuss the effects independently of each other. Although chemical and micro-scale tests like Fourier transform infrared (FITR), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and scanning electron microscope (SEM), etc. have been applied to explain the modification mechanisms, discussions related to different nano-materials and the investigation on a combination of rheological and micro-structural properties are still limited. In fact, an accurate and reliable optimal mixing content has yet to be determined. In this study, bitumen was modified with different contents of CNTs and Gr and characterized from both rheological and micro-structural perspectives. For this purpose, dynamic shear rheometer (DSR), DSC and SEM were utilized to comprehensively evaluate the modified samples. By analyzing the test results, the interaction mechanism between bitumen and CNTs and Gr were determined based on which the optimal contents of CNTs and Gr were recommended for the used bitumen.
2. Materials and testing program
2.1. Materials
2.1.1. Bitumen The control bitumen binder with performance grade (PG) 64–22 is non-modified and was purchased from Panjin North Asphalt Co., Ltd. (China). Its physical properties are shown in Table 1.
2.1.2. Carbon nanotubes and graphene The properties of the thin multiwall carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (Gr) are listed in Tables 2 and 3, respectively. The macro-morphology of the CNTs and Gr are shown in Fig. 1.
2.2. Sample preparation
CNTs and Gr modified bitumen binders were prepared by using a high-speed shear mixer (HSM-100L) to ensure a homogenous dispersion [24]. The 0.2–3% CNTs and 0.2–1.5% Gr (determined by weight) were added to the neat bitumen separately at a temperature of 170 C. The temperature of the CNTs and Gr modified bitumen was maintained at 170 C before undergoing blending in the high-speed shear mixer at 5000 rpm for 30 min which dispersed the agglomerated CNTs and Gr into the bitumen matrix. The mixing procedure has been verified for attaining a sufficiently homogenous distribution of additives.
2.3. Testing methods
2.3.1. Dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) The rheological properties of the bitumen were characterized by DSR. Both the frequency sweep tests and the Multi stress and creep recovery (MSCR) tests were performed using DSR. The frequency sweep tests were conducted between the linear viscoelastic (LVE) region under the strain-controlled modes with the frequency set as 0.1 to 10 Hz and the temperature set as 30 C to 90 C (with 10 C intervals). Parallel plates with a diameter of 25 mm and a gap size of 1 mm were used. The MSCR test was applied to the bitumen binder at 60 C. One loading cycle consists of one a creep period of 1 s and a recovery period of 9 s. The standardized procedure prescribes 10 cycles at 100 Pa, 1600 Pa, and 3200 Pa.
2.3.2. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) To evaluate the thermal properties of the CNTs and Gr modified bitumen binders, the Netzsch Maia F3 System Instrument (NETZSCH Company, Germany) was used to conduct the DSC tests. Binder samples of approximately 5–8 mg were used in the test. The test temperature ranged from 50 C to 90 C, with a heating rate of 5 C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere. Three specimens of each bitumen binder were measured to ensure the reliability of the DSC results.
The glass transition is an endothermic event at which the heat capacity changes significantly. The glass transition temperature (Tg) was therefore selected to quantify thermal properties of the modified bitumen binders.
2.3.3. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) SEM was performed at the HELIOS Nano Lab 600i to validate the microstructure and dispersion of modifiers in the bitumen matrix. The specimens for the SEM were prepared by directly spraying a thin layer of gold onto the samples’ surfaces.
SEM is a type of electron microscope that produces images of a sample’s surface by scanning the surface with a focused beam of electrons in a grid-like scanning pattern. The electrons interact with atoms in the sample, producing various signals that contain information about the surface topography and composition. The
beam’s position is combined with the detected signal to produce an image. SEM can achieve resolutions better than 1 nm. Specimens can be observed under high vacuum conditions in conventional SEM units or in low vacuum or wet conditions in variable pressure or environments as well as under a wide range of temperatures with specialized instruments.
2.4. Test program
The experimental test regime is given in the flow chart as seen in Fig. 2. The CNTs and Gr modified bitumen samples are prepared in the laboratory with different contents. A series of basic characterization tests were then conducted on the modified binders as well as the control bitumen, including DSC, DSR and SEM tests.
Furthermore, pure CNTs an Gr were measured with SEM tests to further support the analysis of interaction mechanisms between the bitumen and the modifiers. The main contributions of this study are as follow:
1. The modification mechanism of CNTs and Gr in bitumen are discussed pertaining to rheological and micro-structural aspects. 2. The optimal dosage of CNTs and Gr is recommended based on a comprehensive investigation with sufficiently varying contents.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Master curves
sections.text:
The master curves of the complex modulus (G*) and phase angles (d) are used to identify the changes in the rheological properties, as seen in Figs. 3 and 4. From Fig. 3, the samples exhibit sim-
art of test program.
s for CNTs and Gr modified bitumen.
ilar behaviors due to the smooth complex modulus. No significant discrepancy is observed in the shape of these curves with or without carbon nanomaterials. Moreover, CNTs and Gr modified bitumen binders show higher G* than the base bitumen at low frequencies, indicate that CNTs and Gr improved the rutting resistance properties of bitumen at high temperature.
From Fig. 3(a), the master curves of bitumen with various CNTs contents are clearly different at low frequencies, but at high frequencies they are almost equal. This illustrate that CNTs mainly changed the performance of bitumen at low frequencies, and thus improved the high temperature performance of bitumen. As the content of CNTs increases, the G* increases. Moreover, a CNT content of 3% exhibits the maximum effects. However, when the frequency is over 1000 Hz, the master curve of 3% CNTs modified bitumen is lower than that of the base bitumen binder, this may be due to the agglomeration of CNTs at low temperature.
As shown in Fig. 3(b), the G* of bitumen with Gr is higher than neat bitumen, and the G* increases as the Gr content increases. This indicates that the addition of Gr can effectively improve the complex modulus of bitumen. Furthermore, the addition of 1% Gr exhibits the best modification effect for bitumen.
The phase angle d reflects the ratio of viscous and elastic components in the bitumen. The smaller the d, the higher the elasticity recovery in the bitumen when the pavements are subjected to traffic at high temperatures [28,29]. From Fig. 4, CNTs and Gr modified bitumen exhibit lower d than the base bitumen, which indicate that the addition of carbon nanomaterials improves the elastic recovery performance of bitumen.
As seen in Fig. 4(a), the d decreases as the content of CNTs increases, this illustrate that CNTs increase the elastic components in the modified bitumen under the same loading conditions. Moreover, for samples with CNTs content of 1% and 3%, the master curves changed their trend and increased at the high frequencies (>1000 Hz). This is contrary to what is expected in a typical master curves for the base bitumen. This indicates that the elastic component of modified bitumen with 1% and 3% CNTs will not increase as the temperature increases.
From Fig. 4(b), When the Gr content is 1% or less, the reasonably smooth curves exhibit a reduction in d with increasing Gr content. In addition, the phase angle of modified bitumen with 1.5% Gr content shows higher d than with 1% Gr content. This indicates that the proportion of the elastic component in the modified bitumen with 1% Gr content is higher than in the sample with a Gr content of 1.5%, this may be due to the different surface morphology and specific surface areas of CNTs and Gr.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Evaluation of the modification index based on the rheological properties
sections.text:
According to [27], the modification of the control bitumen can be evaluated by means of a modification index, expressed as:
Modification Index ¼ Pmodified Punmodified
ð1Þ
where: Punmodified refers to a rheological property measured on the unmodified bitumen such as the softening point, complex modulus and phase angle. Pmodified denotes the same rheological property as measured on the unmodified bitumen but performed after the polymer modification of the bitumen.
The rheological changes induced by the addition of CNTs and Gr can all be classified as favorable for the asphalt. In this study, the complex modulus and the phase angle are measured at 10 rad/s to calculate the modification indexes as shown in Fig. 5. With respect to the complex modulus the degree of modification reaches a peak value around 60 C. This indicates that CNTs and Gr significantly affect bitumen at high pavement service temperatures (around 60 C). At lower temperatures (ambient temperature) the modifiers seem to be inhibited and behave more like the neat bitumen. Generally, the modification with CNTs and Gr result in an increased stiffness of the bitumen while the elastic range is increased. These changes are beneficial to the pavement service life and result in an improved rutting resistance and fatigue performance.
Airey [27] reported that the modification indexes regarding the complex modulus ranged from 2 to 5 for bitumen samples modified by both 5% EVA or 5% SBS. Overall, the CNT modification index of the complex modulus increases as the amount of CNTs were increased whereas the CNT modification index of the phase angle exhibits a reversed trend. A modification with 3% CNTs exhibited excellent results compared to the other CNT modifications. Interestingly, the next three highest modification indexes are for CNT contents of 1.5%, 0.2% and 0.4%; thus, the two highest and the two lowest CNTs contents exhibit the best results. A common challenge is uniform blending of the Nano-scale particles in bitumen due to the agglomeration of particles. It is difficult to ensure the homogeneity of modified binders with low dosages of CNTs. Accordingly, it can be hypothesized that with the dosage over 1.5%, a stable structure with relatively uniform distribution of Nano-particles can be achieved.
With regard to the Gr modified bitumen, all the samples improve the rheological properties significantly, with the exception of the 0.2% Gr modified bitumen. As the content of Gr
increases the modification index of Gr also increases, this trend is only reversed between the two samples with the highest Gr contents. The sample with a Gr content of 1% has the highest modification index and is also significantly higher than that of CNT modified bitumen. At very high temperatures (90 C) the sample with a Gr content of 1.5% performs very similarly to the sample with 1% Gr; at lower temperatures (30 C) the sample behaves more like the bitumen with a Gr content of 0.8%. It should be noted that in order to achieve identical modification effect, the dosage of Gr needs to be beyond 0.8% assuming the critical value of modification index is 3. The modification index of Gr modified bitumen generally exceeds that of CNTs modified bitumen.
Furthermore, a composite sample was created with 1.5% CNTs and 1% Gr (CNTs + Gr). It can be seen from the Fig. 5(e) and (f)
that the composite modification has a better effect that of the individual modifiers. The phase angle was affected by the composite modification and the 1% Gr modification in a similar manner. This demonstrates that Gr plays the dominant role in the modification of viscoelastic properties of the composite modified bitumen. The addition of CNTs only enhances the stiffness modulus.
As the temperature increases, the modification indexes based on the phase angle tend to approach a value of 1 which means that the viscoelastic properties of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen are only marginally affected by the modification at high temperatures. From Fig. 5(b) and (d), it can be concluded that CNTs and Gr are capable of making the bitumen more elastic especially at lower temperatures. The modification indexes based on the phase angle
are relatively similar for 3% CNT and 1% Gr modified bitumen with a modification index around 0.86 at 30 C.

sections.heading: 3.2. Evaluation of modified bitumen by MSCR test
3.2.1. Creep compliance (Jnr) and recovery rate (R)
sections.text:
To characterize the high temperature properties of bituminous materials, SHRP recommends the use of the rutting factor which is calculated with the complex modulus and the phase angle. Angleo [30] describes the MSCR test as a better tool for characterizing the high temperature performance than the rutting factor and suggests that the MSCR test be considered as a super pave high temperature binder criteria. Based on the MSCR test, the non-
recovery compliance (Jnr) and the recovery rate (R) and a stress sensitivity analysis will be used to describe the high temperature properties of the modified bitumen. Fig. 6 displays Jnr and R of all the surveyed bitumen samples at three stress levels.
The R value represents the elastic component of the binder: the higher the R value, the better the elasticity of the binder. The recovery of the original bitumen is always lower than that of CNTs modified samples. It can be concluded that the addition of CNTs increases the delayed elasticity of bitumen. This may be because the original bitumen contains many light constituents, which make the colloid structure become looser. The addition of CNTs can effectively inhibit the destruction of the colloid structure and promote the crosslinking of a solid network, thus improving the elasticity of
ree stress levels.
bitumen [25,26]. When the addition of CNTs is lower than 1%, Fig. 6 (a), (c) and (e) shows that the recovery remains at a similar level. Once the dosage of CNTs is exceeds 1.5%., a significant increase of delayed elasticity can be observed; although it declines a little when the CNTs content is increased further to 3%. The nonrecoverable creep compliance has good correlation with the rutting resistance of modified bitumen, it can be seen from the figure that CNTs can effectively improve the high temperature performance of bitumen. In this study, a bitumen modification with 1.5% CNTs is found to be the optimal content to improve the high temperature performance. This might be attribute to the dispersion of the CNTs in the bitumen. The 1.5% CNTs may be a homogeneous dispersion in bitumen as seen in Fig. 9(c), which improved the bonding force between nanoparticles and enhanced the crosslinking density of bitumen. As the content of CNTs increased to 3%, some agglomerations are observed, as seen in (Fig. 9(d)). The agglomeration of CNTs reduces the bonding force between nanoparticles, decreases the specific surface area and reduces the activity of CNTs, which could counteract the nanomaterials [22].
With regard to Gr modified bitumen, the results in Fig. 6(b), (d) and (f) exhibit similar phenomena as the CNT modified bitumen. For Gr modified bitumen, there seem to be two critical contents, beyond which the delayed elasticity improves significantly. A Gr content of 0.4% is the first threshold after which the nonrecovery compliance of Gr modified bitumen decreases significantly; it then maintains its value until the Gr content reaches 1%. In this study, bitumen modified with 1% Gr was found to be the optimal content to improve the high temperature performance.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Stress level sensitivity analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 7 depicts the stress level sensitivity of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen based on the non-recovery compliance and the recovery. The trend lines for each modified binder were marked with their linear formulae. The regression coefficient is not used to fitting the results precisely but more as a tool to evaluate the sensitivity. Generally, the stress sensitivity of the non-recovery compliance declines after adding the CNTs modifier. The regression coefficient of the control bitumen is 43.388 while that of bitumen with a CNT content of 3% exhibits the smallest value with 13.816. A relatively low stress sensitivity allows the pavement to bear the deformations of dynamic vehicle loadings, thereby extending the pavement service life. It is interesting that an increase of the CNTs does not influence the stress sensitivity significantly. CNTs contents of 0.2% and 0.4% return regression coefficients of 16.008 and 17.41, respectively and thus performs similarly to binder with a CNT content of 3% CNTs. However, when the amount increases to 0.6%, the stress sensitivity increases significantly. Given these differing trends, a precise description of the underlying mechanisms of the modification regarding the effect of CNTs on the stress sensitivity cannot be concluded due to the limited results from this study. The stress sensitivity of the R maintains relatively stable values when the CNTs content is under 1.5% as can be seen in Fig. 7(c). Once the CNTs content reaches 1.5%, the stress sensitivity increases. When the CNTs content is increased from 1.5% to 3%, the stress sensitivity decreases again, which indicates that the increase of CNTs content may not be the underlying reason for the increased stress sensitivity.
CNTs and Gr modified bitumen.
The Gr modified bitumen binders is shown in Fig. 7(b) and (d), exhibited similar behavior as observed for the CNTs modified binders. As the Gr content increases, the stress sensitivity of the nonrecovery compliance gradually decreases. Similarly, the stress sensitivities of the non-recovery compliance for Gr contents of 1% and 1.5% are comparable to each other. The stress sensitivity of the R gradually increases as the Gr content is increased. Therefore, to
Fig. 9. SEM morphology of CNTs modified bitumen binders (a) CNTs, (b) Improvement CNTs.
achieve the best performance of modified binders, the Gr content should be limited.

sections.heading: 3.3. Micro-structure analysis of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen
3.3.1. DSC analysis of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen
sections.text:
The glass transition temperature of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen samples is shown in Fig. 8. The glass transition temperature of the modified bitumen tends to decline after the addition of CNTs and Gr. This demonstrates that the modified bitumen sample requires a lower temperature to change from a highly elastic state to a glassy state, indicating that the addition of the modifiers has a positive effect on the low temperature stability of bitumen. Given the same content, Gr improves the properties more than CNTs, which implies better low-temperature performance of Gr modified bitumen. As the CNTs content increases, the overall glass transition temperature follows more of a fluctuating trend. This may be because the mixture does not reach an ideal state of dispersion due to the low compatibility of CNTs and bitumen as seen in the SEM results.
If the Gr content is maintained below 1%, the glass transition tendency decreases more significantly than that of the CNTs modified bitumen. However, when the content is increased to 1.5%, the glass transition temperature suddenly increases sharply (while it is still lower than the base bitumen). This indicates that the excessive amount of Gr results the agglomeration, which can undermine the low temperature performance of bitumen. When the Gr content is increased to 1.5%, the agglomerations are observed, as seen in
of interface between CNTs and bitumen, (c) Bitumen + 1.5% CNTs, (d) Bitumen + 3%
Fig. 10(c). Agglomerations of Gr acted as focal points of stress and thus weaken the interfacial bonding between Gr and asphalt [20,23–25]. Therefore, the low-temperature performance of 1.5% Gr modified bitumen is not as good as that of 1% Gr modified bitumen. The bitumen with 1% Gr is the most stable sample; this is consistent with the analysis of the rheological test results.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. SEM analysis of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows SEMmorphologies of pure CNTs and CNTs modified bitumen samples. As seen in Fig. 9(a), CNTs are disorderly arranged tubes. Fig. 9(b) shows that the interface between CNTs and bitumen are rough, and the pull-out behavior and significantly intertwined CNTs are observed. The pull-out behavior refers to the fact that parts of the CNTs are linked to the bitumen phase and in the process of interface destruction the CNTs itself dissipate a certain amount of energy as they are pulled out from the bitumen phase. This ultimately delays the destruction of the interface. The intertwined CNTs form a network that enhances the interaction of molecules in the interface region. Khattak et al. [31], pointed out that the pull-out behavior of carbon Nano-fibers enhance the interfacial bonding effect of asphalt. Das et al. [32] also attributed the interface enhancement mechanism of carbon nanotube-based composites to the pull-out behavior of CNTs. As seen in Fig. 9(c), the CNTs are evenly distributed in the bitumen phase. Moreover, high tensile strength of CNTs act as a bridge that connects the bitumen phase and enhance the interface bonding strength. Agglomerations of CNTs are observed in samples with CNTs content of 3% (Fig. 9(d)). The sizes of agglomerated CNTs particles are not unimportant as large particles may result in stress concentrations when subjected to external forces. This may damage the entire system, or
segregate under thermal storage conditions, affecting the modification effect.
Fig. 10 shows the SEM morphology of pure Gr and Gr modified bitumen samples. Fig. 10(a) shows the sheet-like structure of Gr and suggest that the overall surface is relatively flat. Compared to CNTs, Gr exhibits a layered structure and larger specific surface area, as shown in Fig. 10(b), making it easier to blend with bitumen molecules, thus improving the rheological, mechanical and thermal properties of bitumen. On the other hand, the Gr can rapidly adsorb large molecules such as colloids and asphaltene in the bitumen binder; this significantly enhances the material’s rutting resistance, stiffness and thermal properties. From Fig. 10(c), when the Gr content increases to 1.5%, the agglomerations are observed. This may lead to the focal points of stress and weaken the interfacial bonding between Gr and asphalt, thus undermine the rheological property of bitumen and affect the modification effect [25].

sections.heading: 4.1. Conclusions
sections.text:
CNTs and Gr are both carbon based nanomaterials with the same crystal structure, but they have different modification effects of bitumen due to their different surface morphology and specific surface area. To investigate the modification effect of CNT and Gr modified bitumen and describe the interaction mechanisms between bitumen and the respective modifiers, a series of mechanical and micro-structure tests were conducted. Based on the laboratory test results, the main conclusions are as follows:
s (a) Gr, (b) Bitumen + 1% Gr, (c) Bitumen + 1.5% Gr.
CNTs and Gr can enhance the stiffness, rutting resistance, elastic recovery performance, pavement service life and high temperature performance of bitumen. The optimum contents of CNTs and Gr for bitumen binder are 1.5% and 1% by mass of bitumen, respectively. The addition of CNTs and Gr into bitumen remarkably changed the glass transition temperature of the investigated binders, and increased low-temperature performance of bitumen. Gr exhibits a better modification enhancement and compatibility with bitumen than CNTs.

sections.heading: 4.2. Outlook
sections.text:
An effective combination of macro-mechanics and microscopic interactions can help to understand the underlying mechanisms of bitumen modification with carbon nanomaterials. However, the complexity of materials makes it impossible to conduct all the laboratory experiments. In recent years, researchers have begun to use molecular simulation techniques to study the performance of bitumen-based materials.
Research on a molecular scale focuses on the underlying molecular mechanisms and processes. Guo et al. [33] selected four asphalt components (asphaltene, resin, aromatics and saturate) and five minerals (SiO2, Al2O3, CaO, MgO and Fe2O3) to construct the interface model and simulated the interfacial behavior on a molecular scale. Qu [34-36] used molecular dynamic simulations to study the renewable biomaterials and the influence of aging on the physical properties of bitumen binders. The influence of paraffin on the micro-properties of bitumen binders was also investigated by means of a molecular dynamic simulation. Therefore, the research following this study will focus on molecular simulation technology to study the modification mechanisms of carbon nanomaterials on asphalt and the aging of carbon nanomaterials modified asphalt.
Conflict of interest
The authors declared no potential conflict of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

metadata.abstractText: To investigate the rheological and micro-structural properties of bitumen modified with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (Gr), bitumen samples with different contents of CNTs and Gr were manufactured and characterized from both rheological and micro-structural perspective. A frequency sweep and multi stress creep recovery (MSCR) were conducted by dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) to investigate the rheological properties of CNTs and Gr modified bitumen. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) tests were applied to survey the glass transition temperature. The homogeneity of the dispersion and the interaction between bitumen and nanomaterials were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The results indicated that the incorporation of CNTs and Gr enhance the stiffness, rutting resistance, elastic recovery performance, pavement service life and high temperature performance of bitumen. The performance improvements were attributed to an increase in the crosslinking degree of the binders induced by the carbon nanomaterials. Bitumen binders modified with 1.5% CNTs and 1% Gr are found to be the optimal mixtures. Compared to CNTs, Gr is more compatible with neat bitumen and the effect of Gr modification is observed to exceed that of CNTs at the same content. This may be due to the sheet-like surface morphology and larger specific surface area of Gr. 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
